trs: Out there, it’s said, they gave it manioc leaves, they gave it potato leaves, it’s said,

src: hɨd noʔ-ʔëʔ ʔàpyɨʔ=mah, nutèn=hin tɨh wéd-b’ay-áh, mohòy-óh.
trs: they gave it everything, it’s said, that the deer eats today.

src: yúp=mah hɨd nóʔ-óh, hɨd kakàh d’öʔ-k’ët-yö́ʔ=mah, "ʔɨn ʔín=tẽ́h=sud yúw-úh!” no-yö́ʔ pɨ́d,
trs: So they gave it (food), it’s said, (the children) put (the baby deer) in the middle (of the circle they formed), saying “It must be our sibling!”

src: sã́ʔãh=mah pɨ́d=mah hɨd tɨy-d’äh-ham-muhúʔ-úh.
trs: they playfully pushed it back and forth.

imt: thus \textsc{3pl} be.like\textsc{-obl=adv} thus \textsc{3pl} be.like\textsc{-obl=adv} \textsc{3sg} weak-stand-go.about\textsc{-obl=rep} \textsc{dem.itg} \textsc{3sg} strong\textsc{-tel-decl}
src: yɨ́t hɨd nɨ́h-ɨ́t=yɨʔ, yɨ́t hɨd nɨ́h-ɨ́t=yɨʔ, tɨh m’em’em’-k’ët-k’ö́ʔ-ö́t=mah yúp, tɨh pɨb-yɨ́ʔ-ɨ́h.
trs: As they did thus, as they did thus, as it went wobbling about, it's said, it grew strong.

src: yɨ̃-nɨh-ɨy=mah yúp, tɨh kädham-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh, tɨh s’äk-kädham-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh,
trs: As they (playfully pushed the deer) thus, it's said, it took off, it leapt (over them) and took off;

src: hɨd kakàh=yɨʔ=mah yúp, s’ẽ́ç no-kädham-yɨ́ʔ-ay=mah.
trs: it leapt out of the middle (of the circle of children) and took off, it gave a snort \textit{sẽ́ç!} and took off, it’s said.

src: yĩ-nó-óy yẽ́h tɨ́h=ĩh-ĩtíh, sẽ́ç! no-kädham-yɨ́ʔ-ay=mah.
trs: That’s what it said: \textit{sẽ́ç!} and it took off, it’s said.

src: yɨ-nɨh-yö́ʔ=mah yɨ́t=yɨʔ, bahad-nɨ́h tɨh ní-ay-áh, yúp hɨd ín=tẽ́h-ay-áh.
trs: So with that, it’s said, it disappeared, their sibling.

src: yúp won-d’ak-k’öʔ-këy-ʔë́-y yẽ́h=mah yɨ́-d’äh-ä́h, won-d’ak-k’öʔ-këy-ʔë́-y=mah.
trs: They went wandering around looking for it in vain, it’s said, those (children), wandering around looking for it in vain, it’s said.

src: hɨd yë-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh, “Hɨn’ɨ̀h-të́g ʔɨ́n?! ʔɨ́n ʔín ʔɨ́n-àn meh-të́g ʔɨ́n-àn-áh!” no-yö́ʔ=mah,
trs: They returned home, it’s said, saying, “What shall we do?! Our mother will beat us!”

src: tëg=sä̀h b’ɨ́yɨʔ=mah hɨd mug-sud-hitab-k’ãʔ-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh, yúp sáku-an-b'ay.
trs: They filled that sack up with charcoal and hung it up again.

src: yɨ-nɨ́h-ɨ́y=mah hɨd s’om=d'äh tuʔ-k’öʔ-yɨ́ʔ-ɨ́h, hɨd yɨ-nɨh mɨ̀ʔ, mòy hat-hupsɨ̃p-yɨʔ-sɨ̃́w-ɨ̃́y=sud=mah, hɨ́d-ɨw-ɨ́h.
trs: Thus, it’s said, while they were going about bathing, they had apparently already dug (dwelling-)holes, it’s said.

src: yɨkán=mah yúp, moytùd mòy hɨd nó-ow-óh.
trs: Out there, it’s said, curassow (\textit{Nothocrax urumutum}) holes, they call them.

src: yɨkán ʔũhníy yúp mòy-óh.
trs: Those holes were out there, maybe [pointing].

src: yɨ-nɨ́h-ɨ́y=mah, wɨdyë-yɨʔ ní-íy ni-yö́ʔ, “hup-hipãh-nɨ́h nɨg ni-ní-h!” no-yö́ʔ=mah,
trs: So, it’s said, (their mother) having come home, saying, “You all don’t know what’s right (acted irresponsibly)!”

src: hɨ́d-àn tɨh sɨwɨp-sij-d’äh-way-yɨ́ʔ-ɨ́h, hɨ́d-àn tɨh méh-éw-ay, tɨh in, hɨd ʔín-ay.
trs: She whipped them until they (fled) scattering, she beat them, their mother.

src: méh-éy këyö́ʔ=mah yúp, moytùd=d’äh, hɨd hidöhö-ham-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh, hɨ́d=b’ay-áh, tɨh tẽ́h=d’äh k’õh-ʔë̀ʔ=d’äh=b’ay-áh.
trs: Because she beat them, they transformed into curassows, they did, those who had been her children.

src: hɨ́d-àn tɨh=kë́ sĩy’-hũʔ-sɨ̃́w-ɨ̃́y=sud=mah hɨ́d=hin-íh.
trs: They (other birds) had already filled their wings (with feathers), apparently, it’s said.

src: hũtẽ́h=d’äh ni-hṹʔ=mah hɨ́d-àn kë́ hɨd sĩy’-ní-h.
trs: All the birds, it’s said, filled their wings (with feathers).

src: yúp tɨh kë́ sĩy’-hũʔ-yɨ́ʔ-ɨw-ay k’ṍh-ṍy=nih=mah yúp,
trs: Thus with their wings already filled up (with feathers),

src: hɨ́d=hin=b’ay do’kë́y, hɨd ʔín hɨ́d-àn meh-wɨdyë́-ë́t, hɨd do’kë́y, hɨd waydöʔ-kädway-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh.
trs: straightaway, when their mother entered to beat them, straightaway they flew out (of the house).

src: hɨdnɨ̀h käwä̀g-ä́t pɨ́d=mah hɨd hɨʔ-popot=nih-íh.
trs: They (the birds) had also drawn circles around their eyes (as curassows have).'{\footnotemark}\footnotetext{The other birds assisted them in their transformation by filling their new wings with feathers and drawing circles around their eyes.}

src: yɨ-nɨ́h-ɨ́y=mah yúp do’kë́y hɨd moytùd hɨd hidöhö-kädsak-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh.
trs: Thus, it’s said, straightaway they transformed into curassows and (flew) quickly up.

src: opɨ́d hɨd mòy hat-ʔë́y-ay k’ṍh-ṍy=nih-íh.
trs: They had already dug their dwelling-holes.

src: yɨ-nɨ́h-ɨ́y=mah yúp hɨd ham-sij-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh, waydöʔ-ham-sij-yɨ́ʔ-ay=mah.
trs: So like that, it’s said, they went scattering off, flew scattering off, it's said.

src: tãʔã́y=meh-àn=mah tɨh woy-ʔëʔ-yẽ́h-ẽ́h, tãʔã́y-àn=mah tɨh hi-tuk-hi-yet-ʔëʔ-yẽ́h-ẽ́h.
trs: But she (the mother) tried in vain to keep one little girl, she overturned (a basket on the hole to catch) the girl, in vain.

src: yɨ-nɨ́h mɨ̀ʔ=mah, mɨ̀ʔ-ay, s'áh k’öd=sö́ʔ, tɨh hupkäd-kädhi-ní-íy yúw-úh,
trs: As she did this, it’s said, underneath, inside the hole, she (the child) turned around and quickly descended (digging deeper);

src: tãʔã́y=b'ay, yɨ-nɨ́h-ɨ́y=mah nu-sö́ʔ=b'ay tɨh bahad-kädway-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh.
trs: then like this, it’s said, the girl appeared over here (dug up to the surface in a different spot), and quickly went out (and flew away).

src: hup-hipöʔ-nɨ́h-ay ní-íy=mah yɨ́-d’äh-ä́h.
trs: They would not be caught, it’s said.

src: yɨ-n'ɨ̀h hɨd hidöhö́-öw-ay k’ṍh-ṍy=nih.
trs: They had transformed into those (curassows).

src: yɨ-nɨ́h-ɨ́y=mah yúp hɨd ham-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh.
trs: Thus, it’s said, they went away.

src: yúp=mah yúp hɨd ʔín=b’ay ʔot-d’ak-k’ö́ʔ-öp=b’ay-áh, bëbë́ ʔɨn no-të́g-ë́h, bëbë́ ʔɨn no-të́g-ë́h.
trs: Then, it’s said, their mother went following after them crying, like what we call a \textit{bëbë} bird'.

src: yúp=mah yúp tɨh tẽ́h=n’àn tɨh ʔót-ay-áh.
trs: So it’s said, she (went) crying for her children.

src: tɨh tẽ́h=n’àn tɨh ʔot-ʔë́ʔ=yɨʔ, “nɨ̀ põ'ra, nɨ̀ põ'ra!” tɨh no-ʔë́ʔ=yɨʔ=mah, yúp ʔɨd-ham-döhö-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh.
trs: Crying for her children, saying, “My children, my children!” so saying, she transformed (into a \textit{bëbë} bird).'{\footnotemark}\footnotetext{This quoted speech combines two languages: the first word (‘my’) is in Hup, while the second word (‘children’) is in Tukano. As noted above, this multilingual quotation, together with the compound verb ‘say-do-transform' indexes the mother's transformation via the act of crying, i.e. speaking the “language" of the \textit{bëbë} bird.}

src: yaʔàp-ay=nih s’ã́h yúp ʔɨ́d-ɨw-ɨ́h.
trs: That’s all there is to this tale.
